name: Metaphysics
description: Metaphysics is the branch of philosophy concerned with the nature of reality and existence.

name: Epistemology
description: Epistemology is the branch of philosophy concerned with the nature, scope, and limits of knowledge.

name: Immanuel Kant
description: Immanuel Kant is a famous philosopher.

name: Ethics
description: Ethics is the branch of philosophy concerned with moral principles and values.

name: Logic
description: Logic is the branch of philosophy concerned with reasoning and inference.

name: Aesthetics
description: Aesthetics is the branch of philosophy concerned with the nature of beauty and artistic expression.

name: Ontology
description: Ontology is the branch of philosophy concerned with the study of being and existence.

name: Existentialism
description: Existentialism is a philosophical movement concerned with individual existence, freedom, and choice.

name: Idealism
description: Idealism is the philosophical belief that reality is fundamentally mental or spiritual.

name: Realism
description: Realism is the philosophical belief that reality exists independent of human perception.

name: Pragmatism
description: Pragmatism is a philosophical approach that evaluates the truth of beliefs based on their practical consequences.

name: Utilitarianism
description: Utilitarianism is a moral theory that suggests the best action is the one that maximizes utility or happiness for the greatest number of people.

name: Deontology
description: Deontology is a moral theory that judges the morality of actions based on their adherence to rules or duties.

name: Hedonism
description: Hedonism is the philosophical belief that pleasure and happiness are the highest good.

name: Nihilism
description: Nihilism is the philosophical belief that life is without objective meaning, purpose, or intrinsic value.

name: Absurdism
description: Absurdism is a philosophical belief that life is inherently absurd and without objective meaning, yet individuals can create meaning through their actions.

name: Empiricism
description: Empiricism is the philosophical belief that knowledge comes primarily from sensory experience.

name: Rationalism
description: Rationalism is the philosophical belief that knowledge is primarily or solely derived from reason or intellect.

name: Phenomenology
description: Phenomenology is the philosophical study of the structure of consciousness and subjective experience.

name: Solipsism
description: Solipsism is the philosophical belief that only one's mind is sure to exist, and everything else, including the external world and other minds, may not exist.

name: Dualism
description: Dualism is the philosophical belief that reality consists of two fundamentally different substances, often mind and matter.

name: Determinism
description: Determinism is the philosophical theory that all events, including moral choices, are completely determined by previously existing causes.

name: Free Will
description: Free Will is the concept that individuals have the power to make choices that are not predetermined by past events or natural laws.

name: Skepticism
description: Skepticism is the philosophical attitude of doubting the veracity of knowledge claims in many areas.

name: Stoicism
description: Stoicism is a philosophy of personal ethics informed by its system of logic and its views on the natural world.

name: Virtue Ethics
description: Virtue Ethics is a moral philosophy that emphasizes virtues, moral character, and the morality of individuals rather than rules or consequences.

name: Phenomenalism
description: Phenomenalism is the view that physical objects cannot justifiably be said to exist in themselves, but only as perceptual phenomena.

name: Post-Structuralism
description: Post-Structuralism is a late 20th-century movement in philosophy and literary theory, which is critical of structuralism.

name: Deconstruction
description: Deconstruction is a method of critical analysis of philosophical and literary language which emphasizes the internal workings of language and conceptual systems.

name: Structuralism
description: Structuralism is the methodology that elements of human culture must be understood by way of their relationship to a broader, overarching system or structure.

name: Semiotics
description: Semiotics is the study of signs and symbols and their use or interpretation.

name: Aristotle
description: Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist who made significant contributions to numerous fields of study.

name: Scholasticism
description: Scholasticism is a method of critical thought which dominated teaching by the academics of medieval universities in Europe.

name: Theology
description: Theology is the critical study of the nature of the divine, and more broadly, of religious belief.

name: Philosophy of Religion
description: Philosophy of Religion is the philosophical examination of the central themes and concepts involved in religious traditions.
